issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a class named "ExcellencePark" (UML lines and task descriptions), while the exercise title, template repository, and solution repository use the name "ExcellenceLand". This inner-problem inconsistency (UML vs. textual tasks) combined with the cross-artifact name mismatch (problem text asks for ExcellencePark but the template/solution provide ExcellenceLand) will confuse students about which class to implement and what the tests expect. It may cause failing tests or incorrect implementations because constructors/getters and the 'rides' attribute are associated with a differently named class across artifacts.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across all artifacts. Either: (A) Rename the UML class and all references in the problem statement/tasks from "ExcellencePark" to "ExcellenceLand" (recommended if the title/template use ExcellenceLand), or (B) rename the template/solution files and classes from "ExcellenceLand" to "ExcellencePark" and update filenames accordingly. Ensure the task descriptions, UML, template class name, and tests all reference the same class name and that the 'rides' attribute and constructor are defined on that class.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) refers to a class named "ExcellencePark" but both the template repository and the provided solution implement the class as "ExcellenceLand". This mismatched identifier for the same conceptual entity (the park container class with attributes excellencyLevel, excellentEnough and rides) will confuse students: the tasks ask them to declare/implement ExcellencePark while the starter code and reference solution provide ExcellenceLand, making it unclear which class name to use and causing friction when mapping requirements to the codebase.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the park class name consistent across all artifacts. Either: (A) rename the class and file in the template and solution from ExcellenceLand to ExcellencePark (update public class name and file name accordingly and any references), or (B) update the problem statement (UML and tasks) to refer to ExcellenceLand instead of ExcellencePark. Pick one canonical identifier and apply it everywhere so students can unambiguously map the requirements to the provided code.
